awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Estimating the Technology of Skill Formation and Maternal Well-Being
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will study the effects of parental skills and investment on children's cognitive and non-cognitive skills development thus impacting the long term social and economic development of these children in later life.  Previous studies of these effects rely on mothers' assessments of child non-cognitive skills---an assessment that may be biased---and do not account for maternal well-being on the dynamics of the child's cognitive and non-cognitive skill development.  These omissions may affect the results of the effects of parental skills and investments on child development.  The proposed research will use the Millennium Cohort Study (MCS) to study the effects of parental skills and investment on children's cognitive and non-cognitive skills.  In addition to assessment of non-cognitive skills by parents, the data set also contain assessment of non-cognitive skills by teachers and interviewers as well as the physical, mental, and emotional health of the mother.  This will allow the researchers to study the reciprocal link from child to parent may generate important feedback effects on the child's development; therefore, limiting the biases that may arise from the omissions discussed above.   The results of this research project will provide guidance to practitioners, educators and policymakers as they develop policies to improve to improve cognitive and non-cognitive skills of children.  Helping to understand how to improve cognitive and non-cognitive skills among children will result in a stronger work force, thus improving the long-run performance of the U.S. economy. 

Previous studies of the effects of parental skills and investment on children's cognitive and non-cognitive skills development suffer from two potential sources of bias: they rely on the mother's, possibly biased, assessment of the child's non-cognitive skills and do not allow for possible feedback effect the child's cognitive and non-cognitive development may have on the mother's skills.  To address these issues, the PIs will use two features of the Millennium Cohort Study (MCS). First, the MCS dataset collects measures of child non-cognitive skills from mothers, and from interviewers and teachers. Second, the MCS interviews mothers on their mental health and life satisfaction during each wave of the survey. Using this data, the PIs will estimate a technology of skill formation characterized by dynamic, nonlinear production functions where both inputs and outputs are unobserved. Key inputs include contemporaneous child skills, parental skills, and parental investment, while the next period's cognitive and non-cognitive skills for both the child and the mother are the relevant outputs. To achieve identification, the researchers rely on the availability of noisy measures of child skills, parental skills and parental investment each period, following the methodology of Cunha, Heckman and Schennach (2010). The identification of the contamination of mother-assessed child non-cognitive skills relies on allowing the observed measures of non-cognitive skills, as reported by teachers and interviewers, to be a function of both maternal skills and child skills.   The results of this research project will contribute to a better understanding of the link between parental skills and investment and child outcomes and will provide guidance to practitioners, educators and policymakers as they develop policies to improve cognitive and non-cognitive skill development of children.

por.por_cntn:
A growing number of researchers use dynamic latent factor models to study child skills development. These models are well suited to studying dynamic processes where key inputs and outputs are unobserved. In the context of child skills development, important inputs can include past levels of child cognitive and non-cognitive skills, parental skills, and parental investments. The outputs of interest are typically future child skills, and ultimately adult outcomes.

While historically researchers have treated skills as observable, there is an emerging view that no error-free measure of skills or investments exist. Despite this lack of observability, researchers can use dynamic factor models to make progress in understanding the skills development process by relying on the observability of noisy measures of latent skills and investments. Yet, there are important assumptions embedded in mapping observable measures to latent constructs in a dynamic context that have not been fully understood or investigated.

Our contribution to this burgeoning literature is two-fold. The first outcome of our project is a working paper titled, “Skill Formation and the Trouble with Child Non-Cognitive Skill Measures”. Much of the work on child skills development using dynamic factor models focuses on the joint development of cognitive and non-cognitive skills. Noisy measures of child cognitive skills are common in surveys, often taking the form of cognitive tests in the domains of vocabulary, comprehension, and mathematical intuition. However, measuring child non-cognitive skills is more challenging since young children are not capable of reporting on the appropriateness of their own behaviors or mental state. Instead, parents are typically asked to report on child non-cognitive skills.

We show in our paper that parent-reported measures of child non-cognitive skills are directly affected by their own latent skills. For example, a depressed mother may respond differently about the non-cognitive skills of their child than a non-depressed mother. Since parental skills also act as inputs in the production of future child skills, this can generate important biases in our estimates of the skill development process. We develop an approach to mitigate these biases by relying on multiple, imperfect evaluators of child non-cognitive skill. In particular, we show that when teacher-reported measures of child non-cognitive skill are also available, we can identify the impact of input changes on child outcomes.

Taking a broader view, our paper highlights the importance of having quality measures for hard to measure latent constructs. This is not unique to dynamic latent factor models, but is also true for simple policy evaluations. For example, consider an experiment designed to estimate how pre-school attendance impacts child non-cognitive skills. If the mother is the one reporting on child non-cognitive skills and the mother’s well-being is also affected by the child’s pre-school attendance, the measured impact on the child will be contaminated.

While the first project outcome is related to measure quality in the context of dynamic latent factor models, the second project outcome highlights the importance of critical assumptions that link measures to latent constructs. Our working paper titled, “Identification of Dynamic Latent Factor Models of Skill Formation with Translog Production “, which has been accepted for publication at the Journal of Applied Econometrics, studies how to overcome the lack of a known location and scale for latent skill inputs and outputs when identifying dynamic treatment effects. Because skills are by definition unobserved, there is no well-defined mean or variance. In practice, researchers typically set the location and scale of latent skills and assume that this is an innocuous normalization.

In our paper, we illustrate that these location and scale normalizations are generally not innocuous, and that estimates of the skill development process are sensitive to these normalizations. However, we show that researchers can avoid this sensitivity by utilizing a flexible translog production function and focusing on treatment effect estimates rather than production function parameters.

With the support of the NSF, we have been able to devote time to these two projects which we believe significantly advance the state of knowledge on estimating skills production. We expect the first paper will alter the design of future surveys interested in assessing skill development and lead to a re-assessment of previous work that relies entirely on parental measures of child non-cognitive skills. The second paper will likely contribute to changing the standard approach for estimating dynamic latent factor models.

 

Beyond these technical contributions, the broader goal of studying child skills development is to identify key inputs and the optimal timing for producing high human capital children. We hope that improving the standard tools researchers use to answer these questions will lead to more successful policy prescriptions and parental decision making.
